Posts.Content: Dec 3, 2011 06:06PM VSM wrote: I've attached a link (and a few quotes from the site) that I thought might help--your mother is at an age where fibrocystic changes occur. Often with simple cysts there is no extra procedure needed--unless there are other difficulties, the simple cysts can be left alone.  It's important she gets regular exams though to watch for complex cysts. http://www.mayoclinic.com/health/breast-cysts/DS01071/DSECTION=causes "Breast cysts develop when an overgrowth of glands and connective tissue (fibrocystic changes) block milk ducts, causing them to dilate and fill with fluid." "The cause of breast cysts remains unknown. Some evidence suggests that excess estrogen in your body may play a role in breast cyst development." I've also attached a link to a past discussion on cysts that might add some extra information. http://community.breastcancer.org/forum/83/topic/723359?page=1#idx_22 I hope that helps.

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2011 07:57AM VSM wrote: I'll second that Taylor--it's time to see a doctor. There are many things it could be instead of cancer, but get in there and make sure--your health is #1 and when you figure out what it is, you can start getting better (for both issues).  Sometimes we try and ignore the signs our bodies send us, because we fear the unknown.  I hope you will head to a doctor soon to get everything checked out.  It's important to start paying attention to your body now (when you are young), so you will know when something unusual pops up in the future.  Keep us informed--I'm sending calming thoughts tonight!

Posts.Content: Sep 21, 2011 07:48AM VSM wrote: #1  I'm glad you've already got an appointment set up for next week.  #2 Try not to think too far ahead (easier said than done!!!).  The important part is to get the BS to do some exams--a biopsy is the only sure way to know if it is cancer or not, so I'm sorry that the ER doctors decided to say the things they did.  I like to hear things in a straight forward manner, but more tests need to be done before they should give you a "diagnosis..." Speaking with a BS is the next step--please know that many of us are in regular contact with our BS, even though we have not been diagnosed with cancer. Zombean is right--it is good to write things down--I list questions as I think about them and then I go down the list with my BS.  Sometimes things can happen so fast that it feels overwhelming!  Know that you are not alone and we're here for questions, rants, or just to listen/read. Hang in there and make sure to let us know what the BS says!

On a positive note, the doctors feel comfortable having you wait 3 months and get rechecked, instead of calling you back for more tests immediately.  Unfortunately, you need to get some peace of mind or your next 3 months will be very difficult.  Know that it is always alright to call the doctors or clinics and ask questions-after all, it is YOUR body, and you can't make your own decisions about what is best for your own body, if you don't know what you're deciding on.  If you haven't already done so, I suggest that you request your images and the reports so that you know what the doctors have concluded. Hang in there-sending calming thoughts from here!

Urgent Treatment Center?  I originally went to my GYN--they set up the diagnostic Mamm/US and  they immediately set an appointment for mewith a BS they recommended-- I checked back with the results to both the GYN and the BS when there was some confusion and conflicting reports from the radiologist...I wanted to make sure all my questions were answered so I set up an appointment with both. I'd get a recommendation on a good BS--I agree with K-Lo about the "squeaky wheel" and "polite persistence..."  I know a week seems like an eternity away, but it will be hear soon--in the meantime, jump into diversions--let us hear.

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2011 04:28PM VSM wrote: Nikkigerth, I totally understand your anxiety!  I just gave these two sites in another post earlier today, but want to pass them on to you too.  Brown can imply blood, but thank goodness there are so many things it can be besides cancer--BUT it is important that you are getting it checked out.  I went to my GYN first and she set me up with a mammogram (long overdue), diagnostic ultrasound, and an appointment with a breast surgeon.  The breast surgeon did a smear test of the discharge--and both checked on the results of everything.  My results found atypical cells, and I'm playing the "waiting game" (like so many) until a follow up exam.  Don't be surprised if you end up with more questions than answers--we're here to share our experiences if you have questions. http://www.mayoclinic.com/health/nipple-discharge/MY00467 http://women.webmd.com/breast-nipple-discharge

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2011 05:48PM VSM wrote: Nikki, We know how startling if feels--just like Carpediem said, take care of yourself by getting enough sleep--(easier said than done).  Twice I had bloody discharge that was benign--the only way to know is to get it checked out--just a few more days so hang in there!  Sticking with daily routines can help you keep from stressing yourself out too much.  We're here--sending you calming thoughts.  Keep us informed.

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2011 07:35PM VSM wrote: Nikki, I hope you're already offline getting sleep as I write this--sending you support for tomorrow!
Posts.Title: Nipple discharge Nikkigerth VSM

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2011 08:01PM VSM wrote: The technicians doing the mammogram and US were very nice, and comforting...They are not really suppose to say anything--after the exams they went to talk to the radiologists and then a tech and the nurse came back to tell me what would happen for the biopsy (I was to come back for that).  For our clinic it's usually 48 hours for biopsy results.  Know that it is normal to feel nervous--felt pretty surreal to me... Without giving all the gorry details--I heard all kinds of conflicting information between all the techs, nurses, radiologists, and GYN.  In many places now the radiologist does the biopsies, but I didn't feel comfortable with my interactions with him (unfortunately, the doctor we feel comfortable with is not always there for the biopsy)...EVERYONE else in the clinic was noce though and most of them understand your stress and want to calm you. The conflicting information I got in the clinic was a bit stressful for me, so I actually set a follow-up with my BS because I felt he was the one who wanted all of it done in the first place--that took about 2 (painfully long) weeks to get to talk to him.  I would ask whichever doctor you feel most comfortable with/or was the one who requested the exams, etc. I hate to tell you, but in my situation we ended up with more questions than answers--I'm playing the "watchful waiting" game until my next follow up... The unknown is scary, but I want you to know I'm glad you're going to get this done!!  After rereading this, I think I might have made it sound worse than it was....I looked at it as "just another routine checkup" and I was much more calm.  Just remember, you're not alone and we're all sending out our support to you!

Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2011 06:19AM VSM wrote: Amy, I found myself starting to do my breathing exercises (one of my anxiety coping mechanisms...) while I was reading your post.  I can feel your stress through your words--please breathe!  Isn't it crazy how we can be such strong, calm women taking care of issues for others in everyday life, but we let our mind play tricks on us when the issues are our own.  The what-ifs take over--please breathe.  Monday seems like an eternity away, but it will be here very soon.  I've never had a routine exam--always diagnostic with detailed mamm and US--now they are every six months to watch for changes.  My hope is that the radiologist will tell you the results right after the exams--as they have done for me.  Though I don't have cancer, I have had atypical cells and meet regularly with my BS.  The good news is that they want to see more and are sending you for exams to rule out as much as they are to find things. Try to find a diversion this weekend--kids can be the best diversion around!  I'm sending calming thoughts--Let us hear how it goes.

Take one step at a time (easier said than done).  The exams are the next step.  Know that 80% of lumps are benign.  Stress is always hard on our bodies, but stress does not cause cancer.  I'm sending calming thoughts for the weekend--Monday will be here soon so let us now what you find out from the doctors.

Posts.Title: Ductal excision scheduled -what should I expect? Christyne VSM

Posts.Content: Jul 21, 2011 10:57AM VSM wrote: Carolyn, You are very blessed to have a supportive husband!  If you've read many posts on this site, you may be coming to the conclusion that fuzzy and ambiguous answers seem common with breast issues...Those that love us most sometimes have a hard time when they can't "fix" the issues for us.  Your husband and this board will hopefully be of great support. A number of positives jump out when I read your post--you are being proactive and following up on your health care.  Unfortunately, many of us play this waiting game (and we know the game it plays with our minds)--6 weeks seems like an eternity, but it's on the calendar and will get here soon--that's definitely a positive. I've always liked the diagram that Cycle-path posted--it's good to re-read those 80% numbers when panic sets in.  I hesitate to give you the following site, but I like to have information so I can process it. Hope you find it helpful.  The biopsy is the next step to "rule out" as much as it is to find things.  I'm sending positive and calming thoughts. http://www.radiologyassistant.nl/en/4793bfde0ed53
Posts.Title: This is me-not diagnosed but worried atlanta01 MamaMia41

Posts.Content: Nov 14, 2011 02:05AM - edited Nov 14, 2011 02:20AM by VSM Welcome Christyne!  Sorry you are having to go through all this--I have had atypical cells in my discharge too--an excision was recommended and then not...I'm in the "watchful waiting" stage...It's good you are going ahead and getting it done--the peace of mind is worth it.  I've attached a site that explains a little about the procedure.    http://www.breastcareatlanta.com/services/biopsy/duct_excision.html This procedure comes first so they can find out what's in there--what they find will influence what steps are next. Atypical cells means that the "cells are changing"--it does not mean the cells have already changed to cancer--in some cases they never change to cancer, but the duct excision is the next step to get the stuff out.  I'm also attaching a couple of other links I found helpful. http://www.neomatrix.com/healthcare/Nipple-Aspirate-Fluid-Information.aspx http://www.biomedcentral.com/1471-2407/6/164 Others will be along soon--you can also type "duct excision" in the search engine at the top of this page and it will bring up other posts on the subject.  We're here--keep us informed.

Posts.Content: Aug 7, 2011 02:34PM - edited Aug 7, 2011 02:36PM by VSM Painting, weaving, gardening, walking the dog, meals with friends, and the one I always go to (even if only in my mind...) the beach.................My closets and cupboards are immaculate and clothes are even color coded now............. Your kids are the best distractions around--sometimes the simplest of activities can pass the time the fastest--can you beat the heat running through a sprinkler? (I needed a distraction and my DH and I actually did this last month--and we don't have children...) I am so sorry you are having to fight off the mind games during the waiting game!!  We all know how hard it is, and the roller coaster of emotions and what-if thoughts it brings. The good news: even though Tuesday seems an eternity away, it will be here very soon!  Hang in there and let us know what the doctors say.
Posts.Title: conflicted 4minniemousegirl 4minniemousegirl

Posts.Content: Sep 3, 2011 11:30AM - edited Sep 3, 2011 11:32AM by VSM Vamom,  I totally understand your stress!  Take a breath for minute though,  No, I mean it--take a breath.  You have gone through so much already and it's understandable that you have fears for future findings.  All of us on this site know the anxiety, stress, and mind games that breast issues cause-and then there is the waiting...It's so difficult! I'm glad you are writing a list of questions for the BS.  While I tend to want to do my doctor visits alone, you may want to take someone else along to take notes. I would also recommend getting copies of all your exams and results for your own records--that will  also help if you find yourself without insurance and need to have copies to take around with you for comparisons, etc.. If it was me, I would mention the insurance issue to the doctor, BUT do let the stress of the future take over what needs to be taken care of now...I've attached a copy of a site for women with no insurance below, and also want you to know that there are other options you can address when that time comes. I am not facing the chance of a mastectomy right now--but I do know the stress it would cause me if I have to make such decisions in the future.  No matter what the doctors tell you or the decisions that may be needed for your future care, please remember that your health and well being are #1.  Your daughter needs you to be healthy so you can share in the amazing things in BOTH your futures!  Our outside bodies are only the shells that carry our souls through incredible journeys on Earth. Try to take one step at a time (easier said than done...).  When is your appointment with the BS?  Let us hear how it goes, and know that you are in my thoughts until then! Here's the site: http://www.cdc.gov/cancer/nbccedp/ About the Program: Through the National Breast and Cervical Cancer Early Detection Program (NBCCEDP), the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) provides low-income, uninsured, and underserved women access to timely breast and cervical cancer screening and diagnostic services.

Posts.Content: May 20, 2011 11:51AM - edited May 20, 2011 11:51AM by VSM Sissy, I'm glad you have found this site, but sorry you are having these issues.  Discharge can be caused by a number of things--cancer, as well as other things.  I'm not sure how long it has been since your lumpectomy--3 months?  If so, my initial thought is that the continued discharge would not be from the procedure.  The important thing is to be diligent in getting it checked out.  I have had discharge for a number of months now--initial tests showed atypical cells.  The second smear showed no atypical cells, but blood.  Either way, they are continuing to watch for changes.  The "watchful waiting" period is no fun, but I'm glad your appointment is in two weeks.  Keep us informed.

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2011 11:44AM VSM wrote: All the information and confusing messages are overwhelming aren't they!  First, I would suggest getting copies of your films and reports.  Second, I'm not sure if this was an annual mammogram or one ordered by a doctor.  If a doctor sent you, I would schedule a follow-up with that doctor and have them walk you through the reports.  If no doctor was involved, I would schedule an appointment with one.  I wish I knew more avenues for treatment without insurance--maybe others in the discussion will.  Here in KY, our Urgent Treatment Centers charge about $100 upfront for visits without insurance, but you will have a doctor to discuss options with--you might want to call your UTCs for advice and options.  You'll be in my thoughts--let us know what occurs.

Posts.Title: Radiologists disagree, now what?... VSM VSM

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2011 09:16PM - edited Feb 24, 2011 09:18PM by VSM Resaz, Just stick with the doctors and let them do the tests they need.  Each case is unique to the individual.  I went into my GYN with the only symptom of expressed bloody nipple discharge.  I was sent that day to a BS and he did a smear test of the discharge.  The cells came back atypical, a cyst was also expressed--next was the watchful waiting because the mammogram and US did not show a mass.  Skip ahead about 4 months and the discharge is still there...Called the BS and went to see him again today.  He has done a second smear test and I am waiting for the results.  We have decided that if the cells come back normal this time we will wait until my June exams--more watchful waiting...If the cells continue to be atypical, he wants to remove the duct because "he's not in the habit of waiting for cells to continue changing." Make sure to discuss all your questions and concerns with the doctor--if they are focused on your care they will walk you through what they are thinking about your individual situation.  Follow-ups will be scheduled and you will be on their radar so that they may watch for changes. Sending calming thoughts--I know that the waiting and the unknown are the worst!
Posts.Title: intraductal papilloma/DCIS resaz neochiq

Posts.Content: VSM wrote: Thanksgiving weekend I had a dark brown/rust discharge from my nipple-when expressed, not spontaneous.  I went into my GYN (PA), who immediately sent me to a surgeon.  No cancer cells were found when the smear was tested, but abnormal cells were, and I was sent for a diagnostic mammogram and ultrasound. Dec. 10--I had the mammogram and ultrasound.  After the mammogram, I was told by the technician not to be surprised if I was scheduled for a biopsy after the ultrasound, based on what she saw on my images-she said she wanted me to be ready and not shocked if it happened, which I appreciated.  When I asked during the ultrasound if she was seeing "anything," her response was "Yes, and they will biopsy the largest one right above the nipple."  When explaining the biopsy procedures, I asked the nurse if it could possibly just be a cyst, she shook her head and said "No." Dec.14th-I arrived and dressed for my biopsy.  When lying on the table, a woman (I now assume was the radiologist) said that a biopsy was not necessary and it was just a cyst, they would drain it, and no further testing was necessary.  When the same nurse as before joined us with the doctor, I questioned why the 180 degree change in procedure.  The only response, "We have two radiologists, and we see things differently." I'm confused...any comments?   Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Radiologists disagree, now what?... VSM VSM

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2010 04:41PM VSM wrote: Wow--thanks for the instant reply!  They drained it, but that was also a concern...I had my eyes closed...The doctor was having trouble getting into the middle to drain anything--he was using pretty strong force to get there--again, my eyes were closed...The woman, who I assume was the radiologist, said "You didn't get much, do you want the..."  I didn't recognize the name of the tool she referenced.  The doctor's response, "No, I'm satisfied with what I got."  No path will be done, and I got no report of any kind stating what occured and why...I went ahead and set an appointment with my GYN (PA) for Monday to discuss it with her.
Posts.Title: Radiologists disagree, now what?... VSM VSM

Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2010 06:28PM VSM wrote: Great Update: Until this morning, I was feeling pretty alone in all this (except of course for all the wonderful thoughts and advice I got here)-not knowing what steps to take next, what advice to ask whom, and if I should take what the second radiologist said as the final say...especially because he gave me the "all clear"-and who wouldn't want that??!!  BUT, I couldn't get out of my head all that was said by the first radiologist about a need for a biopsy, etc. Well, I went to my GYN today and I feel GREAT!!!  No matter what I face in the next few weeks, I know that I have not just one, but TWO doctors watching out for me!   This is wonderful news, because until I took the initiative and followed up with my GYN, I had no idea that she AND the breast surgeon were following all the procedures and reports being made behind the scenes.   If no one volunteers information, and all this overwhelming news leaves you without knowing the questions to ask, anxiety occurs...so follow your gut feelings and know that open discussions with your doctor help everyone! In summary, my GYN was very confused to see why only a piece of the whole report was followed, and why all but the cyst was overlooked by the second radiologist.  She apologized profusely for not reaching out to me before I got to her, and she noted that the surgeon disagreed with the radiologists findings as well and has scheduled an MRI.   If there is one message I want others who read this to hear, it's follow your gut feelings!  Know that there are NO stupid or insignificant questions!  We must be our own best advocate, educate ourselves, and work as a TEAM with our physicians! Merry Christmas!
Posts.Title: Radiologists disagree, now what?... VSM VSM

Posts.Content: Dec 17, 2010 09:21AM VSM wrote: Thanks to all--My nerves are calmed from your words and advice!  I feel comfortable in the steps I'm taking to see my GYN again and to get the copies of my slides past/present to make educated decisions.  I have had to be my own advocate concerning doctors in the past and I will continue--we must remember that doctors have the education and experience to guide us through, but since I know my body's reactions better than anyone, I must work with doctors that see me as part of the TEAM to keep my body healthy--these doctors are out there and fortunately I've worked with a number of them in the past (and will continue to find another one).  Happy Holidays---wishing all peace and joy during the New Year!
Posts.Title: Radiologists disagree, now what?... VSM VSM

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2010 04:56PM - edited Dec 16, 2010 05:19PM by VSM Thanks lago-- Discussion of a possible papilloma happened on the first visit, but then changed to a cyst on the second.  My sister actually had a papilloma and cyst both removed last year--thank goodness, benign.  She went through a similar thing, but her GYN actually decided to do the biopsy based on her own professional diagnosis, not caring what the radiologist said.  She's in a different state though, so I can't go to her doctor for an opinion.  My gut tells me it is not cancer, and I wasn't worried until they changed their minds--sounds backwards doesn't it...Thanks for acknowledging my concerns everyone!
Posts.Title: Radiologists disagree, now what?... VSM VSM

Posts.Content: Sep 3, 2011 08:09PM - edited Sep 3, 2011 08:12PM by VSM I know the feeling!  I was scheduled for an immediate biopsy from one radiologist and went back 4 days later only to be told it was a cyst...I was excited to hear the good news, but then asked why the 180 degree flip...the only answer, "We have 2 radiologists and we see things differently."  Great, but I'm the one left in the middle of their differing views......................I work VERY closely with my BS to make sure I get all my answers met--keep being proactive! He's the one that found the atypical cells, he's going to watch for changes every six months (along with me...).  It's crazy how we all have to be the experts of our own bodies even if we can't go to get a medical degree...Let me hear how it works out!

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2011 08:32AM VSM wrote: Finally!  I was beginning to think you weren't human... When my dad was really sick a few years back, he worried about some of the things you just mentioned.  I remember having discussions with him, letting him know that it was the strength of my love that had me there for him, just as Rick is there for you.  Life is hard, PERIOD.  You have EVERY RIGHT to feel ANY feelings you are feeling!!  None of us want to be a burden, or cause hardship, or heartbreak on the people we love the most, but isn't that what true love is?  I mean, true love to me is being able to support that person I love, being there (and blessed to be the one chosen to be there) when life gets hard, giving EVERY bit of energy and strength in loving and caring for my loved ones--just being there when the times are good isn't true love to me, it's just being an acquaintance...You might be surprised how much your strength through the years has given Rick strength--strength that will get him through his own hard times! Let your mom and Rick love you!  Rest in their care, and let their love cradle you.  I know how dark our thoughts can be!  I wish you sunshine and laughter today! Another friend with cancer is asking everyone he knows what makes them happy--my response--the little things: sun rises and sun sets...just "being" with my love and our child (dog) Niko...hearing a child squeal and giggle with joy...the changing of the leaves, AND gummy bears for me.......What makes you happy Cin?

Know that you can request copies of all your images and reports--it's good to have them for your own files.  Sometimes I get my copies before I have even gotten in to see the doctor, scheduling appointments can be a pain... Posts.Content: Nov 21, 2011 01:41PM VSM wrote: The duct excision is the next step to finding out what is going on inside the ducts.  Much of the time there is a benign papilloma inside the duct that is causing problems.  While a papilloma is usually benign, it is important to get it checked out because some change...You may want to type the words "duct excision" in the search engine at the top, right of this page.  This is an older post, but there is a more current one that may help you called "Ductal excision scheduled, what should I expect" (you can get to it by typing the words in the search engine as well)--hope that helps.

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2011 03:53PM VSM wrote: MLB24, I'm so sorry you are having to go through these stresses!  Fuzzylemon is right--we have to take care of our bodies--and souls--stress can make everything worse, and we know it is so hard to stay calm when there are so many unknowns...Know that most lumps come back benign, and we'll be here for you with our experiences until you hear the results that come (and after). It's good that you are getting it checked out, and I hope you will be able to keep from reading too much into the faces and opinions from the "team" of people you will see when getting the tests.  I try to have the doctors that refer me to the tests decipher the results--all the techs, nurses, etc, try to help, but sometimes the conflicting information causes more stress...  My advice is to keep to routines as much as possible this week.  Make sure to get enough food, sleep, and FUN!  Our minds spin with worry, but this site is proof that women are stronger than they think--next week may seem like a year away, but it will be here soon. Keep writing here to calm your nerves, vent, and ask questions as often as you need--As a new poster, you will only be able to post 5 times in a 24hr period, but you can send a personal message (PM) to as many people as you wish if you find someone that may have the information you search for--click on their name and send a personal message. I'm sending you calming thoughts--keep us posted.

Posts.Content: Sep 3, 2011 04:46PM - edited Sep 3, 2011 04:47PM by VSM Kelly, Breast changes warrant an expert opinion.  The reason self examination is so important is so we can become "familiar" with our breasts, and then be able to notice subtle changes.  Something that is an issue for you, may not be an issue for me, and sometimes it may appear that information we research is conflicting, when it covers a different situation.  Early detection is the best way to manage and take care of cancer.  Having said that, 80% of lumps are benign--the important part to think about is that we can't diagnose cancer by just "feeling" the lump--other diagnostic approaches are necessary to decide the "seriousness" of the situation. I haven't actually read Dr. Love's book yet, so I can't speak to the point you saw in the book.  I do know that she has focused lots of her time and research on DCIS and the early detection of cancer--even by studying the abnormal fluid cells in the nipple, BEFORE they turn to cancer, BEFORE they even form a lump.  Many (not all) breast cancers are slow growing and can be in the breast ducts for 8-10 years before they can be found on a mammogram.  Should you be concerned about the "seriousness" of a lump?  I say, try and leave the stress out of the equation until diagnostic exams are done and results are found.  Remember, this is YOUR body, and doctors need to diagnose your situation WITH you, not merely acting "upon" you.  Don't be afraid to ask questions--especially if you get conflicting expert opinions (which was my case).  I found a BS that I am comfortable with and he acknowledges and respects my questions, concerns, and personal needs for my OWN body... If we knew all there was to know about cancer, or one procedure worked for everyone, we would be rid of cancer...Be your own best advocate--get regular exams and know your OWN body, so you know when something is not right.  Have you seen a doctor yet? Waiting for results?

Posts.Title: Clustered Breast Calcification, Anyone deal with this? jlw23 VSM

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2011 10:10PM VSM wrote: The good news is that you are getting it checked out now!  It's always important to get any breast changes checked out.  The reason self breast exams are so important is so we can become "familiar" with what our own breasts feel and look like so we can notice subtle changes. I had brown discharge and when the fluid was tested, atypical cells were found.  Those cells may never change to cancer, but we're watching to see how "stable" my changes are.  Blood should always be checked, and your doctor's office has test strips that show whether fluid has blood or not  (Hemastix, I think...).  When I was referred to a BS, he did a smear of the fluid and found the atypical cells. The next time the cells were tested, no atypical cells, but blood was found.  Our watch continues... Know that there is more concern when discharge is from a single breast and a single duct. There are many causes of discharge, including infection.  Sometimes a green discharge can occur from cysts. Having said that--get it all checked out.  I've attached two links to some information about discharge that I found helpful--hang in there and let us know what you hear from the doctor. http://www.hopkinsmedicine.org/avon_foundation_breast_center/breast_cancers_other_conditions/nipple_discharge.html http://www.mayoclinic.com/health/nipple-discharge/MY00467  I'm sending calming thoughts tonight!

Kids are a great distraction--try to find something to get your mind off all this--even if it's just for a short while.  My artwork and garden help a lot--even my closets are all organized and the clothes are even color coded now..............the thoughts and emotions can be so intense one minute and then hopefully they pass for a short while.  The short moments of release will help you build strength for the next time that fear rears its ugly head.   Monday morning will be here soon and you can get an appointment--I'm sending strength and patience your way!

Posts.Content: Oct 28, 2013 08:15PM VSM wrote: Welome Ashley! Our minds jump right to the negative and we stress and worry--I know it is so hard not to. Sounds like it is time to find a good gynecologist, if you do not already have one. Anytime we see or feel changes in our breasts, it's good to get them checked out. Know that our bodies go through so many changes at different ages, and you are at one of those stages (I'm heading into another stage of changes, but at the menopause end). Most of the time the changes are normal, but it's good to get them checked out all the same. There are so many things that might be going on, cancer is only one of many, but it could be something as simple as an infection or hormonal changes that are affecting your breasts. Check with a doctor and let us hear back.
Posts.Title: Could it be cancer? I'm only 15 (almost 16)! ashley98 aaoaao

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2011 09:02AM - edited Jan 8, 2011 09:48AM by VSM BioAdoptMom3,  I'm sorry you've gotten confusing messages.  I have been going through EXTREME confusion since Thanksgiving with mixed messages flowing everywhere.  I know the stress you feel and hope you can get some relief soon.  In summary, my nipple discharge smear found atypical cells-diagnostic mammogram and US were done.  The first radiologist gave me a Birads 4 and biopsy/aspiration recommended with no palpable mass but a duct or cystic mass by the nipple (other enlarged ducts, etc.).  The mammogram tech, US tech, and nurse all gave messages (verbal and nonverbal) that it was more than a cyst and the radiologist needed me back in immediately.  Four days later, a different radiologist announced that it was just a cyst and he would aspirate it and no further testing would be done, because they always come back benign...The reason given for the 180 degree switch from the first radiologist-"We have 2 radiologist and we see things differently." Period-that's it-no more explanation. My gut didn't let it go there and I instigated a follow up with the BS.  He walked me through things and put his head in his hands in frustration when I explained the mixed messages from everyone.  He said he wished I had called him to get it cleared up and to always do so in the future.  He feels very comfortable having me wait 6 months to recheck everything-but also assured me that he was watching things-no palpable mass but atypical cells and he doesn't like that.  He also insisted that I call him immediately if I see any changes before the six months is up. My point in telling you all this-there are doctors out there that are supportive and it is important to find one that you feel comfortable with and does not judge you as "another crazy woman" if you are confused with all the overwhelming information...peace

Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2011 07:07AM VSM wrote: Welcome to the boards!  I know that moving away from the family for the first time is stressful in itself--having a health issue doubles the stress!!  I agree with the ladies, it is probably a skin issue, BUT that does not mean you shouldn't go get it checked out!  The school clinic is a good first step--they will also send you to a specialist if need be.  Then, if you are headed home for the holidays (and it still is not healed) check it out with your family doctor (and your parents care). My rule of thumb: if you are uncomfortable enough to post on this site, it's time to see the doctor.  Good job in getting to know the "normal" status/shape/size/texture/etc. of your breasts--then you can take care of subtle changes as they arise.  Let us know how it turns out.

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2011 03:26PM VSM wrote: First, I am so sorry about the loss of your friend--I lost one of my dearest childhood friends to BC in December too. Second, I am glad you are able to meet with your doctor on Tuesday--we all know how the waiting and the unknown can play tricks with the mind!  I have attached a link to a calcification site but I hesitate to send it before you talk to the doctor...It is so hard to be patient, but please try not to delve too deeply into information before the "re-check." I am the type that likes to have background information though, so I have sent the link on. I assume--and it is only an assumption--but I assume you got a BIRADS 4.  The reason I say that is based on your comment that the radiologist wants a "re-check."  A BIRADS 4 means there is a "suspicious" area and they want to find out more.  Please understand that it does NOT mean cancer--it means the doctors want more information so they can rule out the bad stuff and possibly see if they can find out what is causing the issue.  I too have had a BIRADS4, but no cancer cells have been found--we're in a watchful waiting period--a 6 month recheck will let us see  the stability of the area. Here's the link: http://www.radiologyassistant.nl/en/4793bfde0ed53 I'm sending calming thoughts--Hang in there and keep us informed!

Posts.Content: Aug 20, 2011 04:38PM VSM wrote: Sorry you haven't gotten responses yet--the weekends are usually pretty slow around here...Others will come along to share their experiences. I'm so sorry you are having the stress we all know so well.  Your mind will play tricks and we usually jump straight to the worst possible scenario.  Remember to breathe--80% of lumps are benign.  You're right, it is what it is, so try not to jump too far ahead (easier said than done...). The good news is that they are being diligent and sending you for more exams. Don't be afraid to ask the BS questions.  He/She will be able to discuss biopsy options if necessary--it depends on size, borders, placement, visibility, etc.  It's a good thing that you don't have dense breasts, things are easier to see if not.  I recommend asking for copies of your films and reports to keep in your own records.  I assume you will be on the "watch list" so they can watch for changes over time, and because of your past history.  I'm sending calming thoughts for the weekend!  Keep us informed.

Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2011 08:27PM VSM wrote: Keeping yourself distracted is the best thing to do..........I'm glad you could let your mind release the worry--even if it was for a short time.  We're here if you have questions or just need to vent!

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2011 07:04PM VSM wrote: The worry is completely normal!  Many of us are in the "watchful waiting" club and it SUCKS!  The 6 month checks will look for stability and to find if things are lurking...I am sooo happy for the benign results so far!!!! Yea!!! The worry is fresh right now--I hope it will weaken as time passes--keep posting if you find yourself going through the roller coaster--we get it!

Posts.Title: Biopsy Results Are In!! SueI12345 VSM

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2013 11:08PM VSM wrote: I agree, time for another doctor's visit.  Redness, heat, pain, and changing color of skin is something to get checked out.  Any changes in our breasts should get checked out--though most of the time it is not cancer.  I totally understand your frustration with the past observations, and worry about the future.  Many of us on the boards have had the run--around for years.  The mind can play tricks on us if we let it.  The key is to stay calm and diligent.  You are your own best advocate and if you feel something is not right, try to find a doctor that will stick with you until you get to the bottom of it.  My hope is that you will head back to the doctor and get it checked out--especially since the "root" has been removed; infection can occur.  Keep us informed.
